description:
The future of the universe rests on one young man, Kamui Shirou, who must destroy either the Dragons of Earth or the Dragons of Heaven - two opposing armies. He alone must decide whether humanity should be destroyed to create a purified universe, or whether it should be protected to preserve civilization.

Two oracles, the sisters Hinoto and Kanoe foresee the coming of the Dragons and predict opposite outcomes. Each sister gathers strength and ammunition to insure her own vision for the future. However, neither sister realizes that there is one man who has an even greater power than the Dragons, and that ultimately he will determine the fate of the earth.

Which sister will prevail and how does Kamui fit into their struggle? The answer to this question will forever affect humanity.

(Source: Manga Entertainment)

tags.name: Cosmic Horror
tags.description: A type of horror that emphasizes human insignificance in the grand scope of cosmic reality; fearing the unknown and being powerless to fight it.

tags.name: Super Power
tags.description: Prominently features characters with special abilities that allow them to do what would normally be physically or logically impossible.

tags.name: Post-Apocalyptic
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a world or civilization after a global disaster.

tags.name: Mythology
tags.description: Prominently features mythological elements, especially those from religious or cultural tradition.

tags.name: Angels
tags.description: Prominently features spiritual beings usually represented with wings and halos and believed to be attendants of God.

tags.name: Yandere
tags.description: Prominently features a character who is obsessively in love with another, to the point of acting deranged or violent.

tags.name: Augmented Reality
tags.description: Prominently features events with augmented reality as the main setting.

tags.name: Shrine Maiden
tags.description: Prominently features a character who is a shrine maiden.

tags.name: Urban Fantasy
tags.description: Set in a world similar to the real world, but with the existence of magic or other supernatural elements.

tags.name: Tragedy
tags.description: Centers around tragic events and unhappy endings.

tags.name: Alternate Universe
tags.description: Features multiple alternate universes in the same series.

tags.name: Magic
tags.description: Prominently features magical elements or the use of magic.

tags.name: Gods
tags.description: Prominently features a character of divine or religious nature.

tags.name: Gore
tags.description: Prominently features graphic bloodshed and violence.

tags.name: Urban
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a city.

tags.name: Male Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is male.

tags.name: Shoujo
tags.description: Target demographic is teenage and young adult females.

tags.name: Amnesia
tags.description: Prominently features a character(s) with memory loss.

tags.name: Anti-Hero
tags.description: Features a protagonist who lacks conventional heroic attributes and may be considered a borderline villain.

tags.name: Ensemble Cast
tags.description: Features a large cast of characters with (almost) equal screen time and importance to the plot.

tags.name: Love Triangle
tags.description: Centered around romantic feelings between more than two people. Includes all love polygons.

tags.name: Dragons
tags.description: Prominently features mythical reptiles which generally have wings and can breathe fire.

tags.name: Time Manipulation
tags.description: Prominently features time-traveling or other time-warping phenomena.

tags.name: Conspiracy
tags.description: Contains one or more factions controlling or attempting to control the world from the shadows.

tags.name: Swordplay
tags.description: Prominently features the use of swords in combat.

tags.name: Demons
tags.description: Prominently features malevolent otherworldly creatures.

tags.name: Environmental
tags.description: Concern with the state of the natural world and how humans interact with it.

tags.name: Cyberpunk
tags.description: Set in a future of advanced technological and scientific achievements that have resulted in social disorder.

tags.name: Nudity
tags.description: Features a character wearing no clothing or exposing intimate body parts.

tags.name: Memory Manipulation
tags.description: Prominently features a character(s) who has had their memories altered.

tags.name: Philosophy
tags.description: Relating or devoted to the study of the fundamental nature of knowledge, reality, and existence.

tags.name: Psychosexual
tags.description: Work that involves the psychological aspects of sexual impulses.

node.description: [Website](http://www.clamp-net.com) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/CLAMP_news) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/clamp_4_official/) CLAMP is an all-female Japanese manga artist group that formed in the mid-1980s. It consists of leader [Nanase Ohkawa](https://anilist.co/staff/97292), and three artists who shift roles for each series: [Mokona](https://anilist.co/staff/100802) (もこな), [Tsubaki Nekoi](https://anilist.co/staff/100804), and Satsuki Igarashi (いがらし寒月). Almost 100 million CLAMP tankōbon copies have been sold worldwide as of October 2007. In general, Ohkawa gets her inspiration for the group from everyday events such as dreams or the news. Unlike most manga artists who specialize in a single genre, CLAMP has created a diverse body of work. CLAMP's genres vary widely, from childish and comedic (Cardcaptor Sakura, Clamp School Detectives) to more dramatic and teen-rated (xxxHolic, X) series. Furthermore, drawing from the idea of Osamu Tezuka's Star System as they did in Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle, CLAMP often crossover characters from their own series into their other works, which gives rise to a loosely defined "Clamp Universe".

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/1521695330)

Currently working as a freelancer, having previously worked for [Artland](https://anilist.co/studio/8/) and [D.A.S.T.](https://anilist.co/studio/6255/)

Yuuki graduated from Saitama Prefectural Toda Shoyo High School and has been active in the school's "Manga and Anime Research Interest Club.” He found business in the National Health Insurance but couldn't give up on being an animator, so he left and became an animator instead. Has collaborated with director [Kazuki Akane](https://anilist.co/staff/102416/) many times, including on his most famous work, [The Vision of Escaflowne](https://anilist.co/anime/182/).

He works on doujinshi under the circles The Man in the High Castle and Ubik, both references to the works of American science fiction author Philip K. Dick. The published doujinshi include key animation from his body of work and specially drawn manga. On the other hand, since he worked on Ralphilia Saga by [Akara Arisato](https://anilist.co/staff/149449/), he has been involved in several works as a guest member of the doujin circle La Moon.
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/hamasakina)

Shigeyuki Hayashi, better known by his pseudonym Rintarou, is a well-known anime director.

A film buff ever since he was a kid, he wanted to pursue a career in filmmaking. After having worked as a cel painter in commercial animation, he joined [Toei Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/18/) in 1958 for a brief time working on films such as [Hakujaden](https://anilist.co/anime/4513/) and [Saiyuuki](https://anilist.co/anime/4481/). After having been told that he couldn't work as a director due to not being a college graduate, he moved to [Mushi Production](https://anilist.co/studio/68/) - making his directorial debut as one of the regular episode directors on [Tetsuwan Atom](https://anilist.co/anime/2747/).

In 1972, Rintarou left Mushi Pro to go freelance and to co-found [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11) together with [Masao Maruyama](https://anilist.co/staff/103170/), [Osamu Dezaki](https://anilist.co/staff/100393/) and [Yoshiaki Kawajiri](https://anilist.co/staff/100812/). A few years later, Rintarou got invited to direct [Jetter Mars](https://anilist.co/anime/6087/) at his previously disinterested workplace, Toei Animation. He accepted the offer but didn't join the studio as an employee, making him one of the few people who've directed for the studio while not being an inhouse employee. He continued to direct multiple entries for Toei, including [Arrow Emblem](https://anilist.co/anime/3800/), [Captain Harlock](https://anilist.co/anime/1000/), as well as the 1979 film [Galaxy Express 999](https://anilist.co/anime/1301/), which is still considered by many as his best work.

[Haruki Kadokawa](https://anilist.co/staff/170354/), the president of [Kadokawa Shoten](https://anilist.co/studio/113/), took notice of the commercial success of Rintarou's works and hired him to direct [Genma Taisen](https://anilist.co/anime/1626/), which was the very first film produced by Kadokawa. The animation production was handled by Madhouse, where Rintarou changed his post at this time. There he continued his directorial efforts with numerous films and OVA series.

The older brother of [Masayuki Hayashi](https://anilist.co/staff/161046/).

[Official Website](http://www.xjapan.com/index.html) | [Twiter](https://twitter.com/xjapanofficial) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/xjapanofficial/) | [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/XJapan)

X Japan is the most successful rock group in Japanese history. Led by composer, drummer, and pianist Yoshiki, the band has sold more than 30 million albums, singles, and videos combined, sold out Japan’s 55,000-seat Tokyo Dome 18 times, and played to millions of fans around the world. In the band’s early days, their look and sound sparked a global interest in the Japanese cultural rock phenomenon “Visual-Kei”, a movement X Japan pioneered that spread worldwide.

In 1997, at the height of their success, the band broke up. Four months later, Hide, X Japan’s original lead guitarist, was found dead in his Tokyo apartment. At his funeral, more than 50,000 fans came to mourn his passing. In early 2007, Yoshiki and vocalist Toshl reunited, and later that year X Japan officially reformed.


__Members:__
• [**YOSHIKI**](https://anilist.co/staff/115552) - Yoshiki Hayashi [林佳樹] (b. Nov 20, 1965) – drums, piano, keyboard (1982–1997, 2007–present)
•  **Toshl** - Toshimitsu Deyama [出山利三] (b. Oct 10, 1965) – lead vocals, acoustic guitar, occasional drums (1982–1997, 2007–present)
•  **PATA** - Tomoaki Ishizuka [石塚智昭] (b. Nov 4, 1965) – guitar, backing vocals (1987–1997, 2007–present)
•  [**SUGIZO**](https://anilist.co/staff/156648/SUGIZO) - Yuune Sugihara [杉原有音] (b. Jul 8, 1969) – violin, guitar (2009–present) *as a touring musician* (2008–2009)
• [**HIDE**](https://anilist.co/staff/102199)\* - Hideto Matsumoto [松本秀人] (Dec 13, 1964 - May 2, 1998) – guitar, backing vocals (1987–1997; died 1998)
• **TAIJI**\* - Taiji Sawada [沢田泰司] (Jul 12, 1966 - Jul 17, 2011) – bass guitar, backing vocals (1985, 1986–1992; died 2011)
• [**HEATH**](https://anilist.co/staff/177204) - Hiroshi Morie [森江博] (Jan 22, 1968 - Oct 29, 2023) - bass (1992–1997, 2007–2023; his death)


__Former Members:__
• **TERRY** - Yuji Izumisawa [泉沢裕二] – guitar (1982–1985, died 2002)
• **TOMO** - Tomoyuki Ogata [オガタトモユキ] – guitar (1984–1985)
• **ATSUSHI** - Atsushi Tokuo [德應淳] – bass guitar (1984–1985)
• **EDDIE** - Kenichi Koide [小出健一] – guitar (1985)
• **HALLY** - Yoshifumi Yoshida [吉田良文] – guitar (1985)
• **JUN/SHU** - Hisashi Takai [高井寿] – guitar (1985, 1986)
• **ZEN/XENON** - Kazuaki Mita [三田一光] – guitar (1985–1986)
• **HIKARU** - Hikaru Utaka [宇高光] – bass guitar (1985–1986)
• **KERRY** - Masanori Takahashi [高橋雅則] – guitar (1986)
• **SATORU** - Satoru Inoue (井上悟, Inoue Satoru) – guitar (1986)
• **ISAO** - Isao Hori (堀功, Hori Isao) – guitar (1987)

\*Although Hide and Taiji are deceased, the band still considers them members and introduces them at every concert, with the group going as far as to play audio/video clips of their voice/guitar for some songs.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/西村博之_(イラストレーター%29)

Originating from [Ajia-do](https://anilist.co/studio/30/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/136171134)

A long-serving anime producer, as well as a founder of [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/), [Mappa](https://anilist.co/studio/569/) and [Studio M2](https://anilist.co/studio/6137/). He currently serves as the Chairman of the Board at [Mappa](https://anilist.co/studio/569/).

Maruyama graduated from Hosei University in 1963, and soon after, he found work at [Mushi Production](https://anilist.co/studio/68/) in 1965. It was here that he met many of Madhouse's future staff members. In October 1972, he left Mushi Production together with [Rintarou](https://anilist.co/staff/102305/), [Osamu Dezaki](https://anilist.co/staff/100393/) and [Yoshiaki Kawajiri](https://anilist.co/staff/100812/) and founded Madhouse. From that time onward, Maruyama focused mainly on producing and planning Madhouse's upcoming projects. He also served as the studio's president through the '80s and '90s.

Thanks in large part to his frequent attendance at anime conventions, he has become well-known in America among Madhouse's fanbase. Not simply wanting to emulate past successes, Maruyama frequently says at these events that his goal as a producer is to seek out new challenges that will allow the production staff to keep experimenting. This attitude in part has been the reason why he has encouraged the studio to take on projects that may not seem like sure-fire commercial hits. In addition, Maruyama has long been a supporter of bringing new talents into the animation business, and continues to encourage young people to work in anime.

In 2011, he left Madhouse and founded Mappa. Later in 2016, he left Mappa and founded Studio M2.

(Source: Wikipedia)
_Note: Not to be confused with the [mangaka](https://anilist.co/staff/245226/Yuuichi-Tanaka)._

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/二村秀樹)

Affiliated with [Studio 4°C](https://anilist.co/studio/13/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/168586097)

Koike aspired to become an animator after having seeing [Yoshinori Kanada](https://anilist.co/staff/106398/)'s work on [Galaxy Express 999](https://anilist.co/anime/1301/). During his third year of high school Koike came to Tokyo and quickly got a job at [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/), and got thrown straight into [Yoshiaki Kawajiri](https://anilist.co/staff/100812/)'s projects. He made his debut as an in-betweener on [Phoenix: Karma Chapter](https://anilist.co/anime/2997/) and as a key animator on [Goku: Midnight Eye](https://anilist.co/anime/1879/).

His first venture into directing was in year 2000, when he got to direct the opening of Party 7, a film directed by [Katsuhito Ishii](https://anilist.co/staff/102102/). Koike also acted as the character designer and animation director on the film, getting to fully display his influences from above-mentioned legendary animator Yoshinori Kanada as well as Mike Mignola, an American comic artist of Hellboy fame.

Some time after this began the notoriously lengthy seven year production of [Redline](https://anilist.co/anime/6675/). The film was eventually released in August 2009. Despite the positive critical response, with particular praise for its animation, Redline didn't have a successful run at the box office. It did however see a much greater success after its home release and has since been recognized as a cult film.

A highly prolific and an extremely influential animator.

Know for his experimentation with the timing of keyframes, his dynamic poses, and his peculiar effects Kanada pioneered a number of techniques and concepts that permeated and shaped the Japanese animation industry, influencing not only his peers but also the generations to come.

Kanada's ability and his tendency to be very personal with his drawings, even to the point of ignoring storyboards if the situation required, popularized in the industry the concept of letting the individual animator's talents shine instead of being uniformed into anonymity. This precept is still respected today and it's one of the reasons Japanese animation is so distinctly unique. His career is also a testament to his ethos that expressive and vibrant animation is not achieved simply through increasing the number of frames but through playing with movement, poses and timing.

In the early '00s, Kanada became an employee at Square Enix.

Notable Square Enix titles in which he was credited:

~!
- 2002, Final Fantasy XI (Motion Capture, Animation Director)
- 2005, Musashiden II: Blade Master (Storyboard)
- 2006, Dawn of Mana (Facial Setting)
- 2007, Final Fantasy 4 DS Version (Storyboard)
- 2009, Final Fantasy XIII (Storyboard Director) - *Posthumous credit.*
- 2011, Final Fantasy XIII-2 (Storyboard) - *Posthumous credit.*
- 2012, Dragon Quest X (Storyboard)  - *Posthumous credit.* !~
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/島村秀一)
Originating from Ad Cosmo.

Anime Director. He began his career at [MADHOUSE](https://anilist.co/studio/11/) where he would eventually make his directorial debut with [Claymore](https://anilist.co/anime/1818/). He then notably worked as Assistant Director throughout the [Attack on Titan](https://anilist.co/anime/16498/) adaptation at [WIT Studio](https://anilist.co/studio/858/), and has since continued to serve as Assistant and Episode Director on various projects there.

Affiliated with [WIT Studio](https://anilist.co/studio/858/).

_Note: Not to be confused with the [Producer](https://anilist.co/staff/155543) or other [Director](https://anilist.co/staff/226420) with the same name._

[Website](http://qbo.sakura.ne.jp/masahiko/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/macha_mkun) | [Flickr](https://www.flickr.com/people/39493978@N08/)

In recent years he has also been working as still photographer.

Originating from [Nippon Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/22/). Directs on rare occasions.

Worked for Square Enix in Honolulu, Hawaii together with [Yoshinori Kanada](https://anilist.co/staff/106398/) and others for the first decade of the 2000s and was completely absent from the anime industry because of this. Returned in 2011 and has been active since.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/新井浩一)

One of the founders of [Kinema Citrus](https://anilist.co/studio/290/).
__[Twitter](https://twitter.com/bbkoichi21)__
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/3028907837)
Skills : Piano, Sound engineer
